title: Array.filter()
description: Creates a new array with elements that pass a test condition.
explanation:
Creates a new array with elements that pass a test condition.

Interview focus:
- Core definition and mental model
- Trade-offs and edge cases
- Practical implementation and debugging patterns
- Real production use cases
useCase: Filtering lists, searching, removing unwanted items

interviewQuestions.question: How does Array.filter work?
interviewQuestions.answer: It returns a new array containing only elements for which callback returns truthy.

interviewQuestions.question: What is the time complexity of filter?
interviewQuestions.answer: O(n), because each element is checked once.

interviewQuestions.question: How do you remove falsy values quickly?
interviewQuestions.answer: Use arr.filter(Boolean), which keeps only truthy values.

interviewQuestions.question: What is a subtle bug with filter and object mutation?
interviewQuestions.answer: Filtering does not clone elements. Mutating returned objects can affect original referenced objects.

interviewQuestions.question: How to combine map and filter efficiently?
interviewQuestions.answer: Use reduce for single pass when performance matters, or keep map/filter for readability in normal cases.

exercises.question: Filter active users only from users list.
Filter callback returns object instead of boolean. Is it valid?
exercises.answer: Yes, object is truthy; but return explicit boolean for clarity.

exercises.question: Refactor if-push loop into filter expression.
exercises.answer: Use source.filter(predicate) instead of manual accumulator loop.

exercises.question: Filter products in stock and price > 100.
Filter callback forgets return in braces. What happens?
exercises.answer: All results become falsey and output can become empty array.

exercises.question: Filtering objects then mutating item changes source data. Why?
exercises.answer: Objects are referenced; filter does not deep clone items.
